Posts.Content: Had trouble with veins in my right leg, very painful and swelling up during the FEC-T.  Different of course from the arm vein swelling spoken of here. I felt things rip when I got out of the bath once, and  had a large red lump came up on the side of my calf.  So I started using witch hazel on it, and the painful veins twice a day. Stopped all the pain, and the red painful lump disappeared, also the veins went down. But of course that was my choice to treat myself. I wouldn't recommend it to anyone else without asking their oncologist.
Posts.Title: Tight, painful veins after chemo.

Posts.Content: Had trouble with veins in my right leg, very painful and swelling up during the FEC-T.  Different of course from the arm vein swelling spoken of here. I felt things rip when I got out of the bath once, and  had a large red lump came up on the side of my calf.  So I started using witch hazel on it, and the painful veins twice a day. Stopped all the pain, and the red painful lump disappeared, also the veins went down. But of course that was my choice to treat myself. I wouldn't recommend it to anyone else without asking their oncologist.
Posts.Title: Tight, painful veins after chemo.

Posts.Content: Snowys Mum Hi Hedgewitch, I know what you mean regarding the friends, I let go of a couple of relationships which were too draining. I feed three feral's and very rewarding it is to see their furry faces each day. Good luck with the cream on your skin :) I am glad I am not the only one falling out with so called friends after being diagnosed with cancer and sort of expecting support from friends.  As well as my five wonderful cat friends I also feed the ungrateful farm cat that was abandoned by the two previous owners. I say ungrateful because she tries to rip your hand off if you try to touch her. Which is why the last two people abandoned her, and I took over providing for her.  I tell her she's an ungrateful cat. But then what right have people got to expect her to like them just because they feed her.  Which is why I had to get rid of the car two years ago when it fell to bits. Was it keep the car and get rid of the cats and stop feeding the ungrateful farm cat, and the even more ungrateful wild birds who hate me and leave bird poo all over my outside chair. They all decided the car had to go. Now a dog would have shown gratitude. But did the cats? Well I'll let you work that one out!
Posts.Title: Just joined.

Posts.Content: iwannaliveforever Hi Hedgewitch I completely understand what you mean about people thinking they know best. I am someone who likes to do my research, and it's frustrating when someone just spouts a bit of opinionated claptrap. I would love it if people just asked me questions (and some of my friends do) or just asked how I was feeling and were prepared to listen to the answer. I am lucky that I found this site early, and I come on here when I feel that no one else really gets it. As yet I have not really 'contributed', just asked questions and had a bit of a whinge, and everyone's been lovely.  I hope the rest of your treatment goes well, and that you and the cats make some good, new friends, as life returns to a new normal. With love Lizz X  Hi Liz. Well I thought it made me into a moaner when I talked about people I had fallen out with because of the way they treated me without actually wanting to listen to me. It takes the anger out of how I started to feel towards people when I hear people on the community have had similar problems. What really made me want to punch someone was when I was told I had been given cancer for a reason. I had been given it to teach me something. A lesson to learn. If only people would think what they were saying before opening their mouths.
Posts.Title: Just joined.

Posts.Content: Helen thanks. I try not to be a selfish self centred person. But I just wanted these so called friends of mine to try to understand how I felt. Why couldn't they just ask, instead of telling me how I should feel. Why couldn't they read booklets, or even google it. But no, they just wanted to control me. One friend who had been a friend for nineteen years even had to write a nasty letter to make sure I got the point that she was in the right, and I should listen to her as she knew best. To begin with I was hurt, and blamed myself for not covering up my emotions that had started to break free. Now I just think stuff the lot of them. I actually am relieved to be free of them and their controlling ways.
Posts.Title: Just joined.

Posts.Content: Hi Karen. Nice to hear from you as we are having similar treatment. I looked at the creams etc advised for radiotherapy, but after looking at the ingredients decided to make my own that were not full of alcohols and chemicals like the commercial ones. The last laugh will be on me though if I get the worse case of sunburn effect ever!
Posts.Title: Just joined.

Posts.Content: Hi Callie69. I agree with you that it helps to put things into place just knowing there are others out there. I have read some of the Macmillan booklets and have read how people feel. It is nice to now talk to people going through similar feelings.
Posts.Title: Just joined.

Posts.Content: LittleWren Hi Hedgewitch I too live alone apart from my senile cat. I know what you mean about friends and their advice. I am a great believer in positive thinking and healthy eating but sometimes you just want to be miserable or angry and eat crap. I get really fed up of people telling me inspirational stories about how someone beat cancer just by eating brocolli and meditating.  My friends have been mostly supportive but I have dropped a few - one  told me that now I have cancer no one will want to date me (like that's a priority) and I'd basically die alone riddled with tumours and get eaten by the cat (ok so I exaggerate a little).  I have found this site invaluable. There always seems to be someone who knows exactly what you are going through. Wow Fi. That is how I feel. All the inspirational stories about broccoli etc. I am sure someone was cured by eating broccoli. But what about all the other millions that weren't.  On a lighter note. There seems to be a few animal lovers here on this site. I hope this photo comes through properly. If not perhaps someone will tell me how to do it. Size etc. Last night in the early hours I discovered I had a new pet. A baby kangaroo. A little Joey snuggled in his pouch. If this doesn't come out people are going to think me crazy!
Posts.Title: Just joined.

Posts.Content: Kacang Hi Hedgewitch. Welcome aboard! Such a shame your friends didn't support you. I've been lucky and had a few great people to support me through the whole bc journey. However, I did have a similar experience a few years back when my hubbie had mental health issues. One person in particular, who I thought was a friend ended up being so not a friend. I'm better off without her.  I have 3 cats and one stray who is trying desperately to get us to adopt her. They were a blessing when i was really  unwell. Lots of companionship and support here. Be a frequent visitor. Lynn xx Hi Lynn. Another cat lover. I don't know what I would do without my cats. Probably be in a very dark lonely place. If I let myself have negative thoughts, one of them soon puts me in my place and makes me feel ashamed. They are such a delight.
Posts.Title: Just joined.

Posts.Content: Dreamthief Hedgewitch, that picture is stunning...... Either that Joey is very young or going through chemo too - roughly what age do you think it is ? Think we can assume you 'Come from a land down under'  Something our other resident aussie Kacang will appreciate  :) G n' J LOL. I don't know whether I'm laughing because you took me seriously. Or because you are going along with the joke. That picture I took last night was of my cat Thierry in his cave. He just looked like a joey in his pouch. So I got out the camera. Here he is in his cat guise.
Posts.Title: Just joined.

Posts.Content: I have just joined, well late last night, the macmillan community. I kindly was told by Dreamtheif that the place to post was here. And that firstly I should copy and paste my original mail here. So here it is. I always said I would never join groups. But here I am. I guess night times can get lonely. Just a brief history. Breast cancer diagnosed last November. Op the end of November. Chemo started January. Now I am on the radiotherapy circuit. It will be number 12 in the morning. I'm ER positve. Also HER2 positive and just had my 5th herceptin injection. Also now started on Letrozole. I live alone with my five cats. I retired in 2012 and had to get rid of the car in 2014. Thank goodness for red cross or else I would not be able to get to have treatment. Well that's about it. Got no idea how this groups threads work, so am going to have to find my way around.  Well I have now just got back from radiotherapy number 12. And my weekend now is free!
Posts.Title: Just joined.

Posts.Content: Dreamthief ROFLMAO - OK, you got me...... Hook, Line & Sinker comes to mind  doh!!! In my defence I have been up for work since 4am I was going to say revenge will be sweet,  but if you are a 'Hedge Witch' I had better behave myself and get re-aquainted with some Steeleye Span. Hugs from 'Gullible George' A Hedge Witch. Now I wonder?
Posts.Title: Just joined.

Posts.Content: Hi Mistymoley. Actually it is probably a good job I didn't join at the beginning of my treatment. I lost what friends I had then by snapping at them. I would hate to have done that here and embarrassed myself. I got sick of people telling me to be positive. Sick of people saying they had a friend who had cancer and they were able to do this, that, and the other. And people telling me I'd be fine, then changing the subject. I am normally a very laid back person who agrees with people to keep the peace. But the cancer made me touchy to start with. So I lost all my friends by telling them it wouldn't be the cancer, or the treatment that would kill me, but people stressing me out. Now I just have five cats to support me through this, who don't deliberately upset me. I was fine doing it on my own. Then last night I suddenly felt a bit lonely and decided to join others who knew how I felt.
Posts.Title: Just joined.

Posts.Content: I can't tell whether my aches and pains and sore feet and fingers are from herceptin, or letrozole. Or just left over from chemo. I have just had herceptin number 13 and was told by the nurse that cancer research is doing trials with less chemo, and just nine herceptin injections. Apparently they do this in I think she said Norway and the results are the same as giving double the chemo and herceptin. Too late for us already on the 18 herceptin stint, but a hope for those in the future to have less side effects.
Posts.Title: Herceptin Injection

Posts.Content: Thanks very much sharing for the info on this interesting sounding mag.Going to subscribe straight away.
Posts.Title: Vita, The breast cancer magazine.

Posts.Content: That is a great find. Even if you don't apply for a gift, the very kindness of the people giving something , is a gift in itself. And gives a smile for the day.
Posts.Title: Need a boost?

Posts.Content: I have just signed. Why is it we have to fight to get these cancer drugs to keep us alive. Some years back my area was one of the post code lottery for herceptin where it wasn't available on the NHS. Then a nurse with breast cancer who was HER2 positive took the NHS to court and won. After that every one in the county had to have it. I bet these people who make the decision to withdraw a life saving drug would feel very differently were they to be in the position of needing it.
Posts.Title: petition the government to continue Kadcyla for breast cancer patients...

Posts.Content: JJsailor Hi, Do get your B12 checked. Since having B12 issues I can't eat eggs as they taste metallic. It is the white that does it. Maybe just try the yolk? Once I have had B12 injection it is easier but not perfect. This problem got much worse during and since chemo. Good luck Thanks J. I have to go for blood tests soon, so I will ask about the B12.
Posts.Title: Can't eat eggs after chemo.

Posts.Content: suze99 No problem. I understand about how hard it can be to get transport for hospital appointments/treatment as I have a 82 year mum with mobility problems who lives a four hour drive from me. She has had a nightmare in the past and it can be so expensive if you have to pay someone to take you. In this day and age there should be something in place for people. Take care Sue x I agree Sue. There should be something in place for people. I am sure there must be vulnerable people out there that do give up their treatment because they are refused hospital transport, and can't afford other means.
Posts.Title: Can't eat eggs after chemo.

Posts.Content: SpicedTea Hello, I find that plain water tastes foul: for some reason it's worse from a glass so I've switched to melamine cups. I just had my first Carboplatin/Paclitaxol combo and while I feel a hell of a lot better than on the EC I am beginning to experience mild stomach pains. Anyway, I digress. I am so sorry to hear that transport have been so dreadful...sounds like a complaint to PALs is in order, if you have the strength for it.  Nicky xxx Nicky I didn't find water tasted foul during chemo. What I found for some reason was it hurt my throat. I had a sore mouth and throat and for some reason found swallowing water more painful than food or other drinks. And I have got a leaflet about PALS. as regards to transport problems. But I just can't face any more stress at the moment by complaining.
Posts.Title: Can't eat eggs after chemo.

Posts.Content: I have been vegetarian since I was 15. When I was diagnosed with breast cancer I went vegan. But after a couple of FEC chemos my bloods were really poor due I think mainly to all the D & V. They had already delayed the second chemo and and the NHS transport you have to ring are really hateful and I dreaded keep ringing them and changing appointments. I had been told I couldn't have transport for pre assessments, only for the chemo. I told them they were giving me a death sentence as without the pre assessment I couldn't have the chemo. Their answer was would I like the chemo transport cancelled then. After a long story the cancer centre stepped in and made the NHS transport people give me transport for all my appointments. But I dreaded ringing them as they made me feel I wasn't deserving of transport. So I decided to make myself eat every thing I could in order to get my bloods back up so as I could have the chemo and not have to change the transport dates. I rang up the hospital at one point and told them I was giving up my treatment because of the hassle over transport.. Lucky for me I got a really caring patient nurse who persuaded me I must carry on. Anyhow, back to the point of this post. I decided to go back to vegetarianism so as to have more choice of foods and boiled myself a couple of eggs. I couldn't eat them. Or anything else containing eggs however disguised. I did during chemo find all food tasted disgusting, or had a metallic taste. But now I have got most of my taste back, I still can't touch eggs. Has anyone else found a problem with certain foods whilst having chemo?
Posts.Title: Can't eat eggs after chemo.

Posts.Content: suze99 Hello I'm so sorry to hear you had such a battle to get transport for your appointments. That is shocking. It must have been so stressful having this additional worry on top of your diagnosis. I'm glad you had the support of a caring nurse to get you through.  What a pain it must be finding out a food you previously loved now seems to be off limits. I think a lot of people find that chemo affects their sense of taste. I haven't any experience of it myself but noticed you hadn't had any replies yet to your question so didn't want you to think no one was listening.  I've had a quick look on the net,  and  while I haven't found anything that specifically mentions eggs, I  came across this information on our site here at Macmillan about changes in taste which might be of some use? Breast Cancer Care have an online forum and lots of information too that you may like to look at. Cancer Research UK also have some information on it. Hope some of this is of use. I'm sure you will get some replies from people who have gone through the same thing and can share their personal experiences.  Meanwhile, take care. Hugs Sue x Thank you so much for finding useful links for me Sue. I wouldn't have bothered, it was just that one of the Red Cross drivers said she had come across people that had a problem with eggs, and some with potatoes after chemo. So I thought I would ask.  I am not the only one having a struggle with transport to appointments. The Red Cross used to deal with it all. But now patients have to ring a NHS number who then try to stop you having transport. I have heard some awful tales about people being refused transport. If you can then convince them you really do have to have transport they then send details onto the Red Cross whose drivers then contact you. But if you manage to be able to book transport, they only let you book one week at a time. It's a real battle. I am sure they are only doing their job by trying to weed out people that don't really need the hospital transport. But it's very stressful for those that have no other way of getting to have their treatment.
Posts.Title: Can't eat eggs after chemo.

Posts.Content: Stephjc. I tried smoothies. I found a great pineapple, coconut and something else in it one. But it set off terrible bowel problems. I have never in my life had problems with indigestion, stomach ache, or diarrhoea. But I get the lot now. I thought it would stop after chemo. But before radiotherapy each day I have to not eat, and take Loperamide to get me safely there and back. Like you, I actually found sweet things taste better. Yet before chemo I hardly ever touched sweet things as I didn't like them much. The very word complan makes me urge. But then it would have done before the chemo. In a former life someone must have force fed me the stuff as I can't bear to look at, let alone put it in my mouth.
Posts.Title: Can't eat eggs after chemo.

But after a couple of FEC chemos my bloods were really poor due I think mainly to all the D & V. Posts.Title: Can't eat eggs after chemo.

Posts.Content: Dreamthief Hi hedgewitch  The chemo taste issues can linger, in most cases it does 'sort of' return to normal but Jackie finished her chemo around Nov 2012 and still can't drink coffee and finds all chocolate except Caramac very bitter - also developed a bit of a nut allergy, nothing life threatening but it does affect her throat slightly. Happy to see you have settled into the group, love this place :) G n' J Hi George. And thank you for the info about Jackie's experience.  And yes, I've settled in nicely. Quite a cosy place here.
Posts.Title: Can't eat eggs after chemo.

Posts.Content: Gilly I feel sick every morning when I wake up. It doesn't usually go until mid day or even later. I look forward to food, but am disappointed when I eat it as it is just not the same anymore. I finished my last chemo the end of April. And I must say things have really improved since then. So I am hoping that given more time I will be able to enjoy food again. Before I started the Letrozole I was hungry all the time when I wasn't feeling sick. Now I find I have to make myself eat because I want to be well to get me through the treatment. But food that I used to love just tastes of nothing now. Eating crisps is still a no no as it's like eating dead holly leaves. And pizzas taste like what I imagine cow pats to taste like. Still not a bad thing really as it steers me away from junk food! I blame the Letrozole for a lot of my side effects. But of course having several treatments at once it's difficult to know the culprit.
Posts.Title: Can't eat eggs after chemo.

Posts.Title: Can't eat eggs after chemo.

Posts.Content: Maggie Dot I personally do not take too much notice of statistics. They can be misleading. When were these statistics taken. Were these people my age, had my type of cancer. Did these people have other health problems. What sort of life style did they lead. I think statistics can show the percentage of people that have died from cancer. But nothing about how it relates to me. You can read an awful lot of conflicting things on the internet, and from what people tell you. I have had six lots of chemo, and 15 lots of radiotherapy as well as surgery. I am now on herceptin and letrozole. For me I felt I have made the right decision by accepting all the help I can be given. Doctors and nurses choose this profession because they want to save lives. I also feel with all the steps forward scientist are making to finding a cure for cancer, that even if the treatment I am having now doesn't work, there will be a treatment that will if I get to that stage. In the meantime I feel if I am strong enough to get through all the treatment, then I am strong enough to beat this cancer.
Posts.Title: Is there anyone who had FEC chemo and radiotherapy for breast Ca and...

Posts.Content: JJsailor Hi, Do get your B12 checked. Since having B12 issues I can't eat eggs as they taste metallic. It is the white that does it. Maybe just try the yolk? Once I have had B12 injection it is easier but not perfect. This problem got much worse during and since chemo. Good luck Thanks J. I have to go for blood tests soon, so I will ask about the B12.
Posts.Title: Can't eat eggs after chemo.

I understand about how hard it can be to get transport for hospital appointments/treatment as I have a 82 year mum with mobility problems who lives a four hour drive from me. Posts.Title: Can't eat eggs after chemo.

Posts.Content: Vicki I live out in the sticks and I'm not on the mains. It's spring water and a soak away system thing.I have lived here 17 years and there has never been a problem with the soak away. I finished FEC-T the end of April and never thought about the chemo having an effect on the soak away system. But nothing has exploded, caused a blockage, or created a stink anywhere. So i am presuming all is well. Just hope the fishes in the river haven't grown legs or something!
Posts.Title: Septic tank & effect of chemo on it .... random but ....

Posts.Content: Vicki was only joking about explosions! I wouldn't be worried about a soak away. I would be worried about living in an area where water is recycled from sewage waste. Goodness only knows what you might be drinking. And my veggies are uphill from soak away. The soak away is in the field above the river where sheep graze. But as I'm vegetarian I don't have to worry about that.
Posts.Title: Septic tank & effect of chemo on it .... random but ....

Posts.Content: Rosie 1947 I have never liked taking tablets etc. Can count the number of times on one hand I went to the doctor. I was all for alternative medicine if I ever had a problem. But when the cancer came along I was so scared of dying I took everything they gave me. I also did it for my cats. I couldn't bear the thought of them ending up miserable having to be re homed. So I put up with the surgery, the chemo, the radiotherapy and the herceptin injections. And now it is all over. I have finished the treatment, apart from the ten years of letrozole, I have my life back, and my cats are safe. And yes it was hell at times. I live alone and had no family or friends to support me through it. But I am glad I went through with it. It seems like a lifetime stretched out in front of you with all the treatment. But the time flies by, and suddenly you are at the end. One of my cats found my tumour, and let me know it was there. I felt I owed it to him to do something about it. And I have come out the other side a stronger person. No one can tell you what to do. All I can say is don't make the wrong decision. Make it the right one for you.
Posts.Title: Declining further treatment after breast surgery

Posts.Content: Redd I think it really helps to voice how you feel to people you don't know. I find here that people never judge. You can write how you really feel inside, not how you tell people you know how you don't feel. It can be such a strain to talk about how you really feel. You end up telling people around you that you are alright, it ends up easier that way. But here, to people who you don't know, but who really understand what it's really like to have cancer, and all the emotions that go with it, well you can speak from your heart. People can see the physical side, the hair dropping out, the pale drawn face, the sickness. But they can't see what is really going on inside. That desperate loneliness, the true fear, and the hidden tears. It's good to talk here, because people listen, and care. They are all in that place, the place none of us want to be.
Posts.Title: Not wanting anymore treatment

Posts.Content: Bogus boob. Because it's taking the place of the real one.
Posts.Title: What do you call yours?

Posts.Content: Thanks for that info Sally. I have a cough that I have had since around finishing radiotherapy.I know it's my throat, and not my lungs. I cough up a little mucus a couple of times a day. But again I know that is from my nose/throat and not lungs. But of course this started around the same time as starting the herceptin and then letrozole as well. It's gone on for so long, just over a year that I can't remember the exact time it started. But it makes sense now that it is the letrozole causing it. I saw the oncologist last Tuesday for a check up. She made no mention of letrozole causing it, just said go to your GP if it gets worse! So thanks Sally for settling my mind as to what it is. What would we do without this site to share information the experts fail to tell us.
Posts.Title: Coughing with no other symptoms

Posts.Content: Luka wants to join the online party. He has already started partying and singing Carols in a very loud voice.
Posts.Title: ONLINE PARTY......

Posts.Content: Thanks JollyG. I didn't understand there was an actual real AWAKE thread running.
Posts.Title: ONLINE PARTY......

Posts.Content: I finished chemo May 2016 and hair still a bit curly. It came back as tight curls to begin with. I have had straight hair all my life. As it got longer the curls loosened. Then I cut it off a couple of weeks ago. I thought I would lose the curls completely. But next day the hair started to get a wave to it. A hair dresser friend said it looked a mess after I had hacked it off. She offered to thin it, layer it, and tidy it up. It is very short now, but still has lift to it, and curls at the ends. I love it and hope it stays like it.
Posts.Title: Hair after chemo

Posts.Content: Aloe vera gel rubbed on, and internally is good for the problem. Also to drink the aloe vera juice to work from the inside. It is safe for ER+ breast cancer, and HER2 positive. Best to get organic with no added junk in it.
Posts.Title: Letrazole side effect

Posts.Content: Oops I meant 2015 diagnosed. Sorry.
Posts.Title: Herceptin and diarrhoea

Posts.Content: Hi Sue. I was diagnosed in November 2016. had surgery, chemo, was ER. and HER2 positive. I had horrendous diarrhoea with the FEC. Not so bad with the Docetaxol. But continued having loose stools that are not really diarrhoea, but two or three times a day I need to get to the toilet quick. I always have to put on a pad for safety when I go for hospital appointments. I also take imodium before I go. I blamed nerves for a while when the chemo stopped and there was no reason for the loose stools. But after radiotherapy finished on the 15th June and no more hospital appointments until the 12th July, I couldn't blame stress. So I have been blaming the letrozole which I started with the fourth lot of herceptin. I can't take pain killers for all the back and joint pain, again blamed on the letrozole. I get stomach ache and indigestion that is worse than the pain. At least the pain goes if I sit or lie down, but the stomach ache and indigestion gets worse and lasts for at least 24 hours. I wake up feeling sick each morning which usually is gone by midday. Again blaming the letrozole. But perhaps the three weekly herceptin has silently been causing the problem. But I'm really not sure. I have had so much treatment I really don't know what is causing the loose stools. So sorry I'm not much help really.
Posts.Title: Herceptin and diarrhoea

Posts.Content: See brain fog strikes!!!
Posts.Title: Herceptin and diarrhoea

Posts.Content: I look like a moth eaten Hobbit.
Posts.Title: Amused by my hair

Posts.Content: I look like a moth eaten Hobbit.
Posts.Title: Amused by my hair

Posts.Content: I too finished chemo end of April and I dare not take off my scarf in public. Bits of head hair growing in different directions. Bald bits at the top of each side. Even the fine hair on my arms stands up like its had an electric shock. At least the cats don't care what I look like. They are the only ones allowed to see me without headwear on!
Posts.Title: Amused by my hair

Posts.Content: Jolly good question. I never thought of it, but it makes sense. I tried googling it, but couldn't find a suitable answer. I hope someone else can provide the answer.
Posts.Title: Antibodies

Posts.Content: I too finished chemo end of April and I dare not take off my scarf in public. Bits of head hair growing in different directions. Bald bits at the top of each side. Even the fine hair on my arms stands up like its had an electric shock. At least the cats don't care what I look like. They are the only ones allowed to see me without headwear on!
Posts.Title: Amused by my hair

Posts.Content: All my hair fell out within ten days after the first chemo. I had long hair down to my bottom and my hair had always been my safety comfort zone. It felt good to have it hanging around me. It made me feel like me. What annoyed me was the stupid things people would say. Tales about someone they knew whose hair grew back curly, and a different colour. Those telling me I should colour it purple or pink when it grew back. WHY? And those dummies who knew of someone whose hair never grew back at all. And was I going to get a wig. Get stuffed. Time and time again you would get the stupid remarks. Which is why they got their marching orders out of my life. What annoys me about the advert people are discussing is the fact the participants are not even bald. They have had a short crew cut which is an accepted form of hair cut. I was totally bald. It made me look, and feel like an ugly little old person that had to hide herself away from life, and only feel comfortable around people at the chemo centre where no one took any notice of me because they all knew how it felt. Now the hair is starting to grow slowly back, and I can see the ugly little old person starting to disappear. But what won't disappear is the hurt people inflicted on me with their thoughtless hair jokes at a time when I was at my most vulnerable.
Posts.Title: Does anyone else dislike the Macmillan Brave the Shave campaign?

Posts.Content: Nicky maybe there is a market for pubic wigs. I never had a problem before. But I daren't wee anywhere but in my own toilet because I never know where the wee is going to end up. I made the mistake of weeing at the hospital before a radiotherapy appointment once. Big mistake. Had to go in with damp patch on trousers. Just so embarrassing. Could buy one of those lady wee things I suppose. But then the problem will be solved as soon as the pubes grow back. Hopefully.
Posts.Title: Does anyone else dislike the Macmillan Brave the Shave campaign?

Posts.Content: Also it is embarrassing to admit to not being able to control where your wee goes. So unless someone starts the topic, we tend to just cope in silence. My eyebrows are back, eyelashes starting along with sprouting head hair, but no sign yet down below of anything growing. But I will definitely get one of those shewee things because there is no way I will sit on a public toilet. And I am sic of every time I wee at home it takes off on a journey of its own because its lost its undergrowth to guide it.
Posts.Title: Does anyone else dislike the Macmillan Brave the Shave campaign?

Posts.Content: I wanted to post when I recently started to hear it all the time on the local radio. Then it started to appear on the television. I sort of put up with it before. But this time around it really upsets me and I turn the radio/television off straight away before I damage them. Now it has been mentioned on this site again and felt I just had to add my feelings. I wish these smiling people in the ads had seen me desperately crying my eyes out as my hair that was down to my waist disappeared in a few short cruel days. That was eighteen months ago. It has now grown back. But the painful ugly memory of how I felt losing it still remains.
Posts.Title: Does anyone else dislike the Macmillan Brave the Shave campaign?

Posts.Content: Nicky you mentioned drying yourself with no pubic hair. Yes it is difficult,  I never feel properly dry. Also wee tries to run down your leg into the top of your pants without the pubic hairs to guide it in the right direction. And sorry guys, but it must have been a man that designed the mammogram. If they had to shove their bits into that awful machine I am sure another way of torture would have been developed!
Posts.Title: Does anyone else dislike the Macmillan Brave the Shave campaign?

Posts.Content: I have always loved this. It reminds me to be positive and seek positive energy.
Posts.Title: Uplifting things

Posts.Content: Meat eaters always bring up the fact that vegans also get cancer. Same as people who smoke will tell you Winston Churchill smoked and he lived until he was 94. In fact people will always try to bring up some fact they have heard to prove their point. I think the recent one is broccoli has as much protein as beef. Well tell that to my cats! What I feel is do is what you feel is right for you. But do proper research. Did those vegans get cancer because they were vegan. Or was there another cause. Did they smoke, drink alcohol, and pig out on sugar. I say look at the whole picture, and make up your own mind. Not let someone make it up for you. And don't believe anything you read on the internet, or heard from anyone else until you have researched it properly.
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Actually according to Robert Lanza there is no such thing as death. It's just an illusion. So perhaps anther fact of yours that needs a bit more research.  Sorry. Just had to do that. No offence meant. Just my pathetic sense of humour. www.dailymail.co.uk/.../Quantum-physics-proves-IS-afterlife-claims-scientist.html
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Thanks. I have just googled it. When I was first diagnosed I got so confused with all these miracle diets making a lot of money for the people publishing them. But I am always open to the fact that there may be a diet out there that really can cure cancer. But I am very suspicious of sugar being cut out, and replaced with some other miracle substance so you can still eat sweet things. Most of them actually contain more sugar than refined sugar itself. And hardly any have any clinical backing behind them. When a study was done on honey most of them contained very little real honey. Just sugar and anti biotics and sold as real honey. But to be fair, I will take a proper look at Dr. Johanna Budwigs website and diet. I only skimmed over it and was put off when I saw the sugar alternative. I have read about flaxseed and cottage cheese as a cure for cancer in dogs. But there again, no clinical research details. But I think everything is worth a look at. The cure is out there somewhere!
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: I always said that if I got cancer I would refuse all conventional treatment and go down the alternative route. But when I did get diagnosed in November 2015 I was too scared to do as I had always stated I would. I just wanted it cut out and have any treatment they could give me. Being ER. and HER2 positive scared me, and it wasn't until I started waking up each morning during chemo and being disappointed I hadn't died in the night, that I decided that if the cancer came back, I wouldn't have chemo again. Or for that matter any other invasive aggressive treatment that poisons me to within an inch of my life. But in the meantime I would compromised and start using complimentary medicine alongside conventional. Which is what I am doing now. I feel that if it doesn't help me, at least it won't harm me.
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: chloecat45 Hi Hedgewitch Good for you, girl!  I'm all for empowerment.  Just to put the cat amongst the pigeons I saw another video which recommends conventional (surgery) and alternative for better results.  They feel like me that chemo and radiotherapy are dinosaurs of the past - they do more harm than good.  Complimentary therapies like acupuncture are good as is yoga, reiki, massage, etc.  Getting good sleep (in total dark) is too.  Fixing your diet, exercise, environmental factors, stress management, etc., also contribute to mental and physical wellbeing.  But you don't have to wait.  Start doing them now. ... still fighting this nasty little critter.... Hi Chloecat45. I wish I had been brave enough not to have had the chemo and radiotherapy, just the surgery. But I didn't have the courage. As we all know, the treatment for cancer has basically stayed the same for decades. Surgery, followed by chemo and radiotherapy. I have read both sides of the argument from conventional doctors, to those supporting the alternative approach.  I do believe the harsh treatments from conventional medicine leads to a lot of deaths. But I did hear one bit of sense from a conventional doctor. He said that most people won't stick to alternative treatment because it takes too much effort. Especially when it comes to diet. Following a vegan, sugar free diet is probably very hard for most people. That is why most people prefer to just sit and have their chemo and radiotherapy and let someone do it for them. I did see some truth in what he said. You have to be dedicated to go alternative, and totally believe in what you are doing. I took the middle road, by doing both. Although there is probably a lot of bad reviews about John Kelly's book, I did find it inspiring as he went along the lines of recommending a vegan and sugar free diet to his patients.But to have the chemo and radiotherapy as well.
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Love the kitties and the cuddle bunnies. Here are a couple of pictures of unusual friends. And a big cyber hug sent to anyone that needs it.
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Snowys Mum that is such a relief for you. A real high. I am so glad for you.
Posts.Title: 1st Annual mammo clear.....I am so happy

Posts.Content: I was on FEC -T which I started in January this year. I had horrendous diarrhoea right from the start. I hardly got home from the hour journey from the hospital without having an accident. I had it for ten days up to 15- 20 times a day. Then it did slow down as I took more and more imodium.  And the second chemo was delayed for a week as I lost a stone in weight due to not only the diarrhoea, but sickness as well. They told me that a few people have an enzyme missing, which only shows up when you have  chemo. It gives you the diarrhoea constantly, but you never know if you have this missing enzyme unless you have the chemo. I had to wear ginormous pads and live on imodium. It should have stopped as soon as I started the T part of the chemo. But I was so fearful of it happening that anxiety would set it off the day of treatment. Even now for every appointment I take an imodium just in case. I have never had bowel problems before. But fear of what happened with the chemo has trained my bowels to play up any time I leave for the hospital.  There is a bit about it in this link.  news.cancerconnect.com/.../
Posts.Title: 2 down 4 to go - really bad diarrheoe today

Posts.Content: Glad you made it. I can just imagine your son's face at the way you said "probably."  Not popular mother of the moment I guess!
Posts.Title: Herceptin injection site swelling.

Posts.Content: Carolyn positive thoughts coming your way. Well to the plane you are stuck on. It's amazing what they manage to fly in some poor remote countries. So I'm sure your Luton airport plane can manage it. But in the meantime don't watch any disaster movies. Might put you off  flying! Carolyn you are not the only one finding my rampaging amusing. My near neighbour raises his eyebrows when he sees me with my wheelbarrow and tools and asks what I'm going to hack down next.
Posts.Title: Herceptin injection site swelling.

Posts.Content: Has anyone had problems with bad swelling after herceptin injections. Just had number eight, and for the second time bad swelling reaction afterwards. Number seven I blamed on the nurse slamming it in quickly and and saying "yes it does sting badly" when it hit me like a bee sting and I winced and had to stop myself leaping up. It stung badly for hours and that night I had what I thought was a large bruise and swelling. I measured the bruise so as I had a base line to go on as to whether it got worse overnight. It measured six and a half inches across. The swelling under it went from the side of my thigh from my knee, to hip. It pitted when I put my finger on it. I took pain killers to try to sleep and next morning the dark mark what I thought was a bruise had turned red, and the surrounding swelling was less. So I didn't do anything about it and a couple of days later things were back to normal. I was dreading the injection this time, but luckily it was a different nurse. I told her I had had a reaction the time before and she said she would do it slowly. It did sting a bit to start with, but nothing too bad. But afterwards the area went red and swelled up. Only about three inches across and no further stinging. Now tonight it is up again swelling from knee to hip on outside of thigh with pitting when touched. There is no dark, or red mark now. I have been having a lot of problem with oedema. Every time I do something like a lot of hoovering, or gardening my chest and top of arm areas swell. Also most of the time my ankles are swollen. I have mentioned it, but am told it's the letrozole, or the herceptin. I had an echo a month ago and it was fine. I didn't want to bother people, but it is beginning to worry me a bit.
Posts.Title: Herceptin injection site swelling.

Posts.Content: Thanks Mel. I'll do that.
Posts.Title: Herceptin injection site swelling.

Posts.Content: Thank you every body for the useful info. Carolyn I only had three nodes removed. All clear. I am doing too much like you suggest as next day when I have been doing strenuous things everything swells up, and I'm in a lot of pain. So I have made myself slow down. I feel compelled all the time to get things sorted. I want to get everything in order. I have felt so ill for so many months, now I feel better I want to do things. But my body rebels. As soon as the nurse had gone after giving me the herceptin I went outside hacking a large bush down for an hour. No wonder the leg came up like it did. I do blame the letrozole for all the chest and scars swelling and pain, arm and legs and ankle swelling. But as all the other side effects have died down, I had hoped the swelling and joint pain would. But I guess I don't give it much of a chance. I just wish I didn't have this compulsion to just sort and throw away, and clean everywhere. And this urge to completely rip everything out of my garden and start again. I normally only clean up if someone is coming. And as for the garden, I used to tell people I had let it grow wild for the wildlife.
Posts.Title: Herceptin injection site swelling.

Posts.Content: I went for my echo scan and assessment on Tuesday because I am on herceptin. I have also been on letrozole since middle of May. I have been having a lot of problems with it and asked if I carried on having the problems with side effects could it be changed to something else. I was told it could be changed. But because I was HER2 positive I should try to stick with the letrozole because if there are tumours else where it would shrink them. I had surgery end of November 2015 and some nodes taken out. The nodes were clear. But I was told even though nothing showed up, it only takes one seed to pass the nodes and cancer could set up anywhere. So stick with the letrozole. Now my hospital treatment is good, they are a great team. But I have been told some odd things at times that have turned out not to be true. So I am just wondering how true it is that letrozole shrinks tumours other than breast tumours.
Posts.Title: Letrozole shrinks tumours other than primary breast tumour.

Posts.Content: Thanks George and Lynn for the information. I keep hoping the aches and pains will improve. All the other side effects have. But my movement is getting worse. I walk each day and do gardening and try to fight the pain and stiffness. I keep telling myself I have only been on the letrozole for a couple of months. I'm not sure if the herceptin is adding to the problem. But never mind, if it gets unbearable I will try harder to get it changed to something else, like anastrozole Lynn mentioned she's on. I'm not being a baby over the stiffness and pain. This time last year I was riding horses all over the moors. This morning I couldn't even climb over a gate I came across on my walk. Let alone get on a horse and stay on for miles over rough ground. Such is life when cancer strikes!
Posts.Title: Letrozole shrinks tumours other than primary breast tumour.

Posts.Content: Snowys Mum I too hope it is successful treatment for your friend.
Posts.Title: Letrozole shrinks tumours other than primary breast tumour.

Posts.Content: I've heard putting wine corks in the bed stops night cramps. Never needed to try it myself, but have heard others swear by it.
Posts.Title: Herceptin effects

Posts.Content: Hi Mark. Interesting you should mention the vivid dreams after chemo. I wish I had noted it down when mine started. I'm still getting them now night after night. I know they started during chemo which finished the end of April this year. But I started the herceptin half way through and am now coming up to my 12th injection. But I still get the vivid dreams that seem to take me into a larger than life world where I usually am glad to wake up from and discover they are not real. I wonder if the stress of everything brings them on as I have suffered from sleep paralysis in the past. As for the side effects from the herceptin. It's difficult to tell as I am also on the dreaded letrozole daily tablet. I do get sore feeling feet and sore numb finger tips. But that could be due to the letrozole. I feel like the princess with the pea syndrome. Except I feel every stone and bump when I walk however thick my soles on my boots are. Some days I'm tired and just take it easy. But again that could be left over from all the chemo and radiotherapy. I have just googled vivid surreal dreams and cancer. It seems a few others have it too. But I haven't done any research to see what it might be linked to. I hopefully finish the herceptin in March. I will be able then to see if the dreams end there.
Posts.Title: Herceptin effects

Posts.Content: I have been taking letrozole since May 2016. I had a bone density scan and was told I had osteopenia. So I was prescribed calcium and D3 . My hair before chemo was long, fine and straight. It came back thicker and curly. I was worried about the hair loss with letrozole so I started taking Tesco's hair skin & nail suppement. It has got the same ingredients as the posh expensive stuff. But it is only £3 a box of thirty. Up until the end of 2020 there is an offer of three for the price of two on it. Which makes it only £2 a box. Worth it I think. My hair at the moment is still thick, though not so curly. I will certainly carry on taking the supplement as after fifteen months on letrozole, there is no noticeable signs of hair loss.
Posts.Title: Letrozole -hair loss

Posts.Content: Hi Maria. I started to keep a diary after my second lot of chemo.To begin with it was just a log of my side effects which I found useful later. I could check up after further treatment if side effects were the same. I would get something I thought was new, but after checking what had happened before, would find it wasn't new. Then when emotions set in I started to add feelings I was unable to tell people I had. Hopefully if something happens to me I will have time to burn the diary as I would never want people to read some of the things I have said. Which I meant deeply at the time. But felt different about at other times. Although I can only read back at the physical symptoms, not the personal feelings, it has helped me to be able to talk out my innermost real feelings. Even though be it only to myself. This years diary is full of all the pain I have gone through. Next years diary is going to be full of all the joy I bring into my life. It's going to be the new stronger me that doesn't have to write about all the things that have made me cry. I am glad this subject has been brought up as it might help others be encouraged to start their own journey in a diary. I wish I had started a diary from the very beginning. But what has been written, has in many ways been a big comfort to me.
Posts.Title: Keep a diary

Posts.Content: Hi nicnic. I have always wanted smaller boobs. I used to ride welsh ponies in ridden classes at shows all over the country for the boss I worked for. I always wanted small boobs, and long thin legs to look good riding in the show ring. As I had large boobs and short legs I was top heavy. And when I reached pension age, my boobs had reached my waist almost. When I got breast cancer my surgeon gave me the choice, mastectomy on the cancer boob, and a rebuild, or cancer removed and large reduction to both. He said in my case because I had always wanted smaller boobs, and because of their drooping large size, the reduction was best for me. I asked him to take off both. But he wouldn't. I said take loads off, he said he would. I said what if you don't get all the cancer, he answered he would go in again. Well nicnic, all I can say is I have now got the boobs I always wanted. I don't even ever have to wear a bra. They are like teenage boobs. I have got a long way to go as I'm ER and HER2 positve. So I have the horrid letrozole, and the three weekly herceptin. But I have perfect boobs. Which is a nose snub to cancer. It hasn't been able to completely ruin my life. Pity about the long thin legs I've always wanted. But then I suppose you can't have anything. I
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy with breast reduction - when might this be offered?

Posts.Content: Hi Debs. You have had lots of advice. All I can add is that I too live alone with my five cats. I got all sorts of warnings about not letting the cats sleep with me, lick me etc. I was even told to foster the cats out or re home them as they would be too much for me. I of course took no notice. It was my cats that would get me through this cancer thing. My reaction to people was it was not the animals that would infect me, but humans with their filthy germs. My only concern was them jumping on my chest after surgery. But they seemed to know mum was in pain and steered clear of my chest area. I had FEC - T and herceptin and finished radiotherapy on the 15th June. Yes it was difficult at times. But I find being responsible for animals seems to always give you the strength to care for them however bad you feel.
Posts.Title: Living alone and having chemo
